activities.message: This is intentional setup as BEAST is considered as something what should rather be fixed at the client side (see https://blog.qualys.com/ssllabs/2013/09/10/is-beast-still-a-threat or https://raymii.org/s/tutorials/Strong_SSL_Security_On_nginx.html#The_BEAST_attack_and_RC4). AFAIK only reasonable way to address BEAST is disabling TLS 1.0 completely, what would block several clients from accessing the website completely. Do you have some good reasoning for addressing BEAST server side?

activities.message:
Hi nijel, Thank you for your quick response. 

I do believe that BEAST is completely a Client Side Vulnerability . All you can do on the server side is to avoid letting unaware clients put themselves in a BEAST-vulnerable position. 

However, modern clients (Web browsers) are not vulnerable to BEAST anyway:
Clients use record splitting (usually 1/n-1) as a countermeasure. BEAST requires the hostile in-browser code (in Java or Javascript) to be able to send requests to the target site with arbitrary byte values; no method for doing that is currently known.

A client that is still vulnerable to BEAST is a client that has not been updated for several years, which means that it already has bigger problems. A more general solution is to use TLS 1.1 or 1.2, which are not vulnerable to that specific attack. However, even when clients support such protocols, they also tend to indulge in unbridled reconnections that make them vulnerable to protocol downgrade attacks.

activities.message:
The server side solution blocks many users from Windows 7, older Androids and probably some other minor browsers. What made finally to look at the stats and basically don't have anybody using these, so I've disabled anything but TLS 1.2 on the server.

We might need to revert this decision in case of negative feedback from our users though.

activities.message: Yeah nijel you are right. I do support users concern here. But for the safe side you should keep TLS 1.1 and 1.2 support rather than having TLS 1.0.

activities.message: Currently the blocker turned out not to be the web browsers, but some automation scripts using wget running on old Ubuntu, which does not support TLS 1.1. Currently it's not easy for customer to upgrade, so we have to keep TLS 1.0 enabled for now.
